would like to understand the definition of `MetaStore`. 

In my mind, `MetaStore` is only an access layer on physical metadata repository:

1.  In runtime `BeamSqlEnv.SchemaPlus` holds tables loaded from various sources. The load flow looks like: 
*physical_metadata_store* --> *meta_store* --> *TableProvider* --> *BeamSqlEnv.SchemaPlus*

2.  `MetaStore` is responsible to 1) convert a table metadata entry to `BeamSqlTable` with `TableProvider`, 2) save a `BeamSqlTable` as a metadata entry. 

3. `BeamSqlCli` should bind one configurable `MetaStore` by default, and be able to load tables from other `MetaStore`s;

Changes Unknown when pulling **3481958177bb5b384f5294b5999e680bc448dc3c on kennknowles:DirectRunner-overrides** into ** on apache:master**.

We definitely want to support the same side input being passed multiple times. Also, I'm all for improving the Do relabeling (though ideally counters would simply be rolled up so one wouldn't need to worry about exact, internal structures). 

The split('/')[-1] should be just fine.

We may want a single `AsSideInput` instance to be passed to multiple different transforms - and this will be no problem. But what about the following:

    pcoll  = 'create_si' >> Create([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
    pcv = AsIter(pcoll)
    result =  Create([1,2,3]) | beam.Map(lambda x, it1, it2: some_function, it1=pcv, it2=pcv)
    # Passed twice into same ParDo

With my current change, we'd have two transforms with the same `full_label` (e.g. `'AsIter(create_si.out)'`), and that may cause trouble with the UI. Should I make sure to support this case?
R: @tgroh OR @kennknowles
looks good to me.
R: @kennknowles @ssisk

okay! I've done some reorganization.

They boil down to:
* TestRow is now a First Class Class - abstract out everything that I think is generic and could be used by other tests related to passing around data, and it pairs well with HashingFn.
* JdbcTestDataSet -> JdbcTestHelper - there is still some code that I want to share between the unit tests and the ITs.

These aren't quite the abstractions you asked for, but I think they're helpful and get at the root of what you were asking - "what can we refactor/share in this code?"

Yes, we should make sure to support this case. It wouldn't be hard to add a
counter in case a side input is used more than once.

On Mon, Jul 10, 2017 at 5:20 PM, Pablo <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> We may want a single AsSideInput instance to be passed to multiple
> different transforms - and this will be no problem. But what about the
> following:
>
> pcoll  = 'create_si' >> Create([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
> pcv = AsIter(pcoll)
> result =  Create([1,2,3]) | beam.Map(lambda x, it1, it2: some_function, it1=pcv, it2=pcv)
> # Passed twice into same ParDo
>
> With my current change, we'd have two transforms with the same full_label
> (e.g. 'AsIter(create_si.out)'), and that may cause trouble with the UI.
> Should I make sure to support this case?

Coverage increased (+0.2%) to 70.871% when pulling **7a152e852fefc1ca4385d8bc3dc4c3b0969f3048 on jasonkuster:pipeline** into **84682109b9ff186f8c850a0b71de5163949c2769 on apache:master**.
Agree with @XuMingmin that use `location` + `tblproperites`(sometimes) to determine the table type(bounded vs unbounded)

1. TableProvider's responsibility:
  a) Generate a `BeamSqlTable` from a `create table` statement.
  b) Provides API to query all the tables of this kind of tables. e.g. For txt tables, it is always an empty list, since there is no persistent storage to hold the meta. While if we have a HiveTableProvider, all the tables in hive is provided by the Hive Meta database.

2. `MetaStore` aggregates all the tables from all the table providers and expose a facade api to `BeamSqlEnv.SchemaPlus` to use. So there will be only one `MetaStore` for one `BeamSqlCli`, you can define your own `MetaStore`, but you can only use one every time.

3. So the load flow is:

> physical_metadata_store --> TableProvider(there can be many providers) -> meta_store --> BeamSqlEnv.SchemaPlus
retest this please.
Merged, feel free to close. Thanks!
